frames.processing

Class Shape

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.primitives.Frame
      • frames.core.Node
        • frames.processing.Shape
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Grabber

    public class Shape
extends Node
    A shape is a Node specialization that can be set from a retained-mode rendering Processing PShape or from an immediate-mode rendering Processing procedure. Either case the shape is split in two a front and a back shape. The front shape will be used for rendering and the back shape for picking with exact precision by default, see Node.setPrecision(Precision). When picking a shape it will be highlighted according to a highlighting policy, see setHighlighting(Highlighting).

    Picking in an exact manner is costly. If performance is a concern, use a Node.precision() different than Precision#EXACT or a simpler representation for the back shape.

    Retained mode

    To set a retained mode shape call set(PShape) which will set both the front and the back shape to be the same pshape. Call setFront(PShape) and setFront(PShape) to set different pshapes for rendering and picking, respectively.

    Immediate mode

    To set an immediate mode shape override set(PGraphics) which will set both the front and the back shape to be the same graphics procedure. Override setFront(PGraphics) and setFront(PGraphics) to set different graphics procedures for rendering and picking, respectively.

    Picking

    Picking a shape is done according to a precision which can either be: Precision#FIXED, Precision#ADAPTIVE or Precision#EXACT. Refer to the Node documentation for both, Precision#FIXED and Precision#ADAPTIVE. The default Precision#EXACT precision use ray-casting of the pointer device over the projected pixels of the back shape. To set a different precision, use Node.setPrecision(Precision). See also Node.precision().

    Highlighting

    The shape may be highlighted when picking takes place according to a highlighting() policy as follows:
    1. Shape.Highlighting.NONE: no highlighting takes place.
    2. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT: the front-shape (see setFront(PShape) and setFront(PGraphics)) is scaled by a 1.15 factor.
    3. Shape.Highlighting.BACK: the back-shape (see setBack(PShape) and setBack(PGraphics)) is displayed instead of the front-shape.
    4. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT_BACK: both, the front and the back shapes are displayed. The back shape is made translucent

    Default is Shape.Highlighting.FRONT. Set the policy with setHighlighting(Highlighting)).

      • setHighlighting

        public void setHighlighting(Shape.Highlighting highlighting)
        Highlights the shape when picking takes place as follows:
        1. Shape.Highlighting.NONE: no highlighting takes place.
        2. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT: the front-shape (see setFront(PShape) and setFront(PGraphics)) is scaled by a 1.15 factor.
        3. Shape.Highlighting.BACK: the back-shape (see setBack(PShape) and setBack(PGraphics)) is displayed instead of the front-shape.
        4. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT_BACK: both, the front and the back shapes are displayed. The back shape is made translucent

        Default is Shape.Highlighting.FRONT.

        See Also:
        highlighting()

      • setPrecision

        public void setPrecision(Node.Precision precision)
        Description copied from class: Node
        Sets the node picking precision.

        When Node.precision() is Node.Precision.FIXED or Node.Precision.ADAPTIVE Picking is done by checking if the pointer lies within a squared area around the node Node.center() screen projection which size is defined by Node.setPrecisionThreshold(float).

        When Node.precision() is Node.Precision.EXACT, picking is done in a precise manner according to the projected pixels of the visual representation related to the node. It is meant to be implemented by derived classes (providing the means attach a visual representation to the node) and requires the graph to implement a back buffer.

        Default implementation of this policy will behave like Node.Precision.FIXED.

        Overrides:
        setPrecision in class Node
        See Also:
        Node.precision(), Node.setPrecisionThreshold(float)

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Same as draw(scene.frontBuffer()).

        Call it only instead of Scene.traverse().

        See Also:
        Scene.traverse(PGraphics)

      • draw

        public void draw(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Draws the shape into pGraphics using the current point of view (see Scene.applyTransformation(PGraphics, Frame)).

        This method is internally called by Scene.traverse(PGraphics) to draw the node into the Scene.backBuffer() and by draw() to draw the node into the scene main Scene.frontBuffer().

        Call it only instead of Scene.traverse(PGraphics).

      • visit

        public void visit()
        Description copied from class: Node
        Procedure called on the node by the graph traversal algorithm. Default implementation is empty, i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes.

        Hierarchical culling, i.e., culling of the node and its children, should be decided here. Set the culling flag with Node.cull(boolean) according to your culling condition: 

         
 node = new Node(graph) {
   public void visit() {
     //hierarchical culling is optional and disabled by default
     cull(cullingCondition);
     if(!isCulled())
       // Draw your object here, in the local coordinate system.
   }
 }
        Overrides:
        visit in class Node
        See Also:
        Graph.traverse(), Node.cull(boolean), Node.isCulled()

      • set

        public void set(PShape shape)

      • setBack

      • track

        public final boolean track(float x,
                           float y)
        A shape may be picked using 'ray-picking' with a color buffer (see Scene.backBuffer()). This method compares the color of the Scene.backBuffer() at (x,y) with the shape id. Returns true if both colors are the same, and false otherwise.

        This method is only meaningful when this shape is not an eye.

        Overrides:
        track in class Node
        See Also:
        Node.setPrecision(Precision)
